I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
financing,  by  way  of  funded  participation  (or  other  similar  instrument)  and  partial  credit 
guarantee  (PCG)  of  principal  and  (potentially)  interest  without  government  guarantee  to 
Deutsche  Bank  AG,  Jakarta  of  up  to  $10,000,000  (or  rupiah  equivalent)  to  finance  the 
acquisition  and  eventual  securitization  of  two  portfolios  of  motorcycle  loans  (Portfolios)  by 
Deutsche  Bank  AG,  Jakarta  branch  (DB)  from  a  motor  cycle  company  (the  Company)  in 
Indonesia (the Project). 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: BACKGROUND, CHALLENGES, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Key Macroeconomic Considerations 

1. 

Credit Background 

Indonesia  underwent  considerable  risk  compression  in  late  2005  because  of  high 
2. 
inflation  and  consequent  high  interest  rates.  However,  these  rates  have  been  gradually 
declining  through  the  first  half  of  2006.  All  in  all,  the  underlying  economy  remains  intact  and 
well-supported by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which are estimated to account 
for  over  50%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  (with  trading  and  agriculture  dominant)  and 
about 10% of exports.  
 
3. 
The  country’s  credit  risk  profile  balances  improvements  in  public  finances  against  the 
need for further reduction in the country’s external finances.1 Two structural changes are seen 
as  affecting  the  economy  in  the  near  term.  First,  the  non-oil  and  gas  economy  is  gaining  in 
importance  as  Indonesia’s  oil  and  gas  balance  is  now  approximately  neutral  and  higher  oil 
prices no longer have a significantly positive effect on the economy. Second, stronger economic 
growth in Japan is beneficial to Indonesia, given the close trade and investment links between 
the  two  countries.  Indonesia  is  rated  BB-  by  Fitch,  Ba3  by  Moody’s2 and  B+  by  Standard  & 
Poors (S&P). 
 

 

2. 

Credit Outlook 

4. 
The  credit  outlook  hinges  on  the  Government’s  ability  to  maintain  macroeconomic 
stability  and  monetary  policy  credibility,  while  implementing  a  demonstrated  reform  agenda 
aimed at increasing the investment climate to attract more inflows. 3 
 
5. 
The rating agency Fitch expects GDP growth to remain at around 5.2% in 2006, below 
the  government’s  5.9%  forecast.  Economic  weakness  attributable  to  higher  inflationary 
expectations  and  interest  rates  will  probably  last  until  third  Quarter  2006.  Rp  stability  remains 
the lynchpin of the Indonesian economy given its close links to inflationary expectations, policy 
credibility and the interest rate environment. 
 

                                                 
1   Indonesia’s fiscal deficit position was equivalent to 0.5% of GDP in 2005, well within the budgeted 0.9%. According 

to the rating agency Fitch, this is better than its ‘BB’ median of 3.2%. Fitch, 2006. Indonesia. 

2  Recent upgrade as at 24 May 2006 
3   In addition, it will also be vital to increase competitiveness of exports. The reversal toward a current account deficit 
position does not come at an opportune time when amortization payments falling due will be heavier over 2006–
2008 and the risks of portfolio securities outflow or further accumulation of external assets by domestic residents 
also weigh on the balance of payments. 

  2 

The Government’s ongoing commitment to strict fiscal discipline and the maintenance of 
6. 
primary balances should, however, provide scope for the public debt burden to continue on its 
downward path, albeit at a slower pace, given the weaker near-term economic outlook and the 
environment of generally high interest rates. It is forecast that the country’s general Government 
debt level will drop to 41% of GDP in 2006.4  
 
B. 

Finance Sector Overview in Indonesia  

1. 

Banking Sector and Retail Banking 

7. 
The  number  of  banks  operating  in  Indonesia  has  been cut almost  in  half  from  the  pre-
crisis  level  of  239  to  133  banks  at  the  end  of  2004.  This  is  because  of  the  closures  and 
consolidation that occurred during and after the Asian financial crisis.5 The generally successful 
recapitalization  and  restructuring  of  the  sector  by  the  Government  post-crisis,  followed  by  a 
more robust operating environment over 2003–2004, saw the industry’s asset base restored to 
much stronger levels by the end of 2004. As a share of GDP, banking system loans continued 
to lag pre-crisis levels at 24% of GDP in 2004 versus 55% in 1996.6 
 
8. 
The retail banking market has expanded rapidly since the Asian financial crisis. From the 
end of 1999 to the end of September 2005, commercial banks’ total lending to individuals grew 
by  a  compounded  average  growth  rate  (CAGR)  of  44%  and  outpaced  the  21%  increase  in 
overall banking system loans. Retail lending has grown to about 30% of banking system loans 
by  September  2005  (10%  in  1997).  Forty–five  percent  of  individual  lending  is  attributed  to 
personal  transportation  loans,  especially  for  motorcycles,  which  has  led  this  growth  (20% 
residential mortgages, 10% credit cards, and 25% microcredits and other personal loans).7 
 

2. 

Nonbank Finance Sector  

The  nonbank  financial  institutions  comprise  multi-finance  companies  (more  typically 
9. 
referred  to  as  finance  companies),  insurers,  and  pension  funds.  As  of  September  2004,  there 
were 238 finance companies operating in Indonesia with total assets of Rp79 trillion, which was 
equivalent  to  6.5%  of  the  total  asset  base  of  the  commercial  banks.  This  is  up  from  3.5%  in 
2000 reflecting the strong recovery in domestic consumption in recent years which has, in turn, 
fuelled  demand  for  the  financing  of  cars  and  motorcycles  (considered  an  essential  good  for 
most Indonesians). As a result, most finance companies have shifted their focus away from their 
traditional business of leasing and factoring to consumer financing. 
 
10. 
In the 4 years ending on 31 December 2004, loans extended by finance companies grew 
by  a  17%  CAGR  led  by  a  43%  CAGR  in  consumer  financing.  These  are  almost  entirely  for 
consumer  lending  purposes,  comprising  mainly  motorcycle  and  automotive  loans,  and  can 
amount  to  1–3  times  the  size  of  their  on-balance  sheet  consumer  receivables  for  the  larger 
players  in  the  industry  (i.e.,  Astra  Sedaya,  Federal  International  Finance,  Adira  Finance  and 
Wahana  Ottomitra  Multiartha).  Finance  companies  are  prohibited  from  taking  deposits  (and 
raising funds from the retail public in general) and therefore depend on borrowings (mainly from 
the banks) and the issuance of bonds for their funding needs.  
                                                 
4   Which is lower than the 46% ”BB” median, according to Fitch, 2006. Indonesia. According to Fitch, the Government 

needs to increase revenue from 19% of GDP towards the 25% median levels reported by its “BB’” peers. 

5   The  ‘”leaning-up”  continued  in  2004  with  three  smaller  banks  having  their  licenses  revoked  because  of  solvency 

issues. 

6   For more details on the Indonesian banking sector, please refer to Appendix 1. 
7   For more details on the motorcycle financing market, please see below, chapter III.B. Please refer to Appendix 2 

for more details on the retail banking and consumer lending market in Indonesia. 

  

 

 

3

 
11. 
Existing and future growth opportunities have increased the need for these companies to 
tap other investor classes for the provision of debt capital and to explore ways of financing via 
factoring, forfeiting, or securitization. 
 
C. 

Securitization: Overview 

1. 

The Global Scenario  

12. 
Securitization  has  emerged  as  one  of  the  dominant  means  of  capital  formation 
throughout  the  world,  particularly  in  the  United  States  (US)  and  Europe.  Each  year  trillions  of 
dollars of securitization transactions are structured by a wide range of entities such as financial 
institutions,  secondary  mortgage  companies,  auto  financiers,  leasing  companies,  credit  card 
issuers, infrastructure and insurance companies, governments, local authorities, and others. 

13. 
Asset-backed  securitization  (ABS)  is  a  highly  structured  financing  technique  that 
provides  an  entity  with  an  economical  means  of  financing  without  the  added  burden  of 
increasing  debt  and/or  equity.  In  its  simplest  form,  securitization  is  a  process  whereby  the 
revenue  stream  of  a  segregated  pool  of  financial  assets  (receivables)  is  repackaged  into 
tradable securities issued to investors. The receivables are sold by the owner (the “originator”) 
to  a  specially  incorporated,  off-balance  sheet  company  or  trust,  known  as  a  special-purpose 
vehicle (SPV). The SPV will pay, with funding received from the issue of securities, the (par or 
net present) value of the receivables it has purchased with no recourse against the originator for 
nonperformance of the underlying debtors (except in the event of certain defects relating to the 
underlying receivables and their sale and transfer).. 

14. 
In developed markets, asset securitization serves a number of purposes: (i) supporting 
public  policy  objectives  such  as  broad  home  ownership  and  the  development  of  financial 
markets  (especially  capital,  retail,  and  mortgage  markets);  (ii)  addressing  regulatory 
requirements 
limit 
requirements  applicable 
the  context  of  
in 
nonperforming assets, and portfolio diversification; and (iv) providing finance. 

institutions,  especially  capital  adequacy  and 

transferring  risk,  especially 

to  banks;  (iii) 

financial 

lending 

for 

2. 

Securitization in Asia 

15. 
Although securitization has gained wide acceptance in other parts of the world, it is still 
in  its  nascent  stages  in  most  of  Asia.  In  the  Republic  of  Korea,  banks  turned  to  securitization 
following  a  stringent  period  of  bank  restructuring,  adding  an  extra  measure  of  liquidity. 
Elsewhere in Asia, securitization is still not commonly being accessed. Regulations, prudential 
guidelines,  and  laws  in  most  Asian  markets  are  yet  to  be  defined  to  promote  or  regulate 
securitization.  In  some  jurisdictions,  authorities  require  banks  to  obtain  the  consent  of  the 
borrower before packaging and selling the loans. This stricture impedes the time-honored Asian 
tradition  of close-knit,  long-standing  relationships  between  bankers  and  clients.  Bankers  worry 
that informing the borrowers of a decision to securitize will imply that the borrower is regarded 
as a risk, and they are unwilling to convey that impression. However, there is a strong argument 
favoring the growth of asset securitization in countries with developing capital markets as well 
as  in  the  more  mature  ones.  Many  Asian  countries  are  uniquely  positioned  to  gain  from  the 
evolution of securitization in the region. 

16. 
For Asian corporations, asset securitization provides a new and potentially cheaper form 
of financing. For loan originators such as banks and nonbank finance institutions, securitization 
is  a  means  of  removing  assets  from  the  balance  sheet  while  retaining  most  of  the  economic 

 

  4 

benefits  associated  with  the  assets,  and  of  freeing  up  capital  to  support  further  loan 
underwriting, while better matching assets and liabilities.  
 
17. 
For  investors  in  Asia,  including  banks,  unit  trusts,  and  pension  funds,  the  securities 
issued  offer  yields  exceeding  those  on  comparable  corporate  bonds  while  providing  an 
opportunity to diversify a fixed-income portfolio by adding another class of securities.  
 
18. 
Securitization  is  already  proving  to  be  an  important  option  for  governments  seeking  to 
promote  private  sector  growth  and  access  funding  for  infrastructure  development.  In  addition, 
and because asset-backed and mortgage-backed deals are usually large and have high credit 
ratings, the securities tend to be liquid and may be actively traded in secondary markets. This 
promotes  capital  market  development  and  enhances  the  competitiveness  of  regional  financial 
centers. 
 
D. 

Securitization and Capital Markets in Indonesia 

1. 

Securitization in Indonesia 

19. 
The  securitization  market  was  in  its  infancy  before  the  Asian  economic  crisis  of  1997. 
Before the crisis, asset securitization was an attractive option for Indonesian commercial banks, 
burdened  by  a  liquidity  mismatch  and  struggling  to  clean  up  their  balance  sheets.  PT  Astra 
International completed a $200 million auto loan ABS in August 1996. The last completed deal 
was  a  motorcycle  ABS  from  finance  company  Putra  Surya  Multidana.  The  $144  million  issue 
closed in October 1997, exactly 1 day after the region's stock markets crashed.8  
 
20. 
The  crisis  has  effectively  halted  new  ABS  transactions  in  the  country.  Currency  and 
interest-rate  uncertainties  made  it  difficult  for  swaps  and  insurance  providers  to  price  their 
premiums  and  made  these  providers  unwilling  to  render  service.  Similarly,  international 
investors were unwilling to invest fresh money as the risk was considered too high to justify the 
expected  returns.9 In  addition,  while  the  regulatory  framework  seeks  to  promote  securitization, 
its cumbersome and unclear processes effectively hinder these transactions.  However, banks 
and other finance companies are expected to turn to securitization once again to improve capital 
adequacy ratios ahead of the implementation of Basel II. 
 
21. 
Since  the  1997  crisis,  the  first  and  only  securitization  transaction  that  closed  was  the 
$600  million  cross-border  future  flow  securitization  for  the major  Indonesian  energy  group,  PT 
Bumi Resources, backed by coal exports generated by two of its subsidiaries, PT Kaltim Prima 
Coal and PT Arutmin Indonesia in June 2005.10 
 

2. 

Indonesian Bond Market 

 
22. 
The bond market suffered greatly during the 1997 economic crisis. There were no new 
issuer  listings  in  1998.  Meanwhile,  the  outstanding  issuers  encountered  difficulties  in  paying 
interest and principal at maturity of the bonds. In 1999, the bond market regained strength and 
achieved its peak growth in 2003. In that year, corporate bond activities, involving conventional 
bonds  and  Islamic  bond  offerings,11 picked  up  significantly.  Total  issues  increased  by  67.9% 

                                                 
8  Davies,  Rob.  2005,  13  June.  Indonesian  Coal  ABS  Surprises.  Asset  Securitization  Report—Source  Media. 

Available: http://www.securitization.net/article.asp?id=1&aid=4602. 
9 Harianto, Farid. The Mortgage-Backed Securities Market in Indonesia.  
    Available: http://www.adb.org/Documents/Books/Mortgage_Backed_Securities_Markets/3_indonesia.pdf.  
10 However, their transaction was structured outside the existing securitization framework. 
11  Islamic bonds, based on Sharia principles, play a major role in the Indonesian capital market. 

  

 

 

5

and the number of issuers increased by 34.0% over that of the previous year.12 The growth in 
the bond market continued until mid-2005, as global and domestic interest rates dropped, and 
investors, mainly in Asia, jumped at the opportunities for higher yields in Indonesia.  
 
The  Surabaya  Stock  Exchange  is  the  primary  listing  agency  for  government  and 
23. 
corporate  bonds  in  Indonesia,  with  103  corporate  bond  issuers  and  243  of  listed  issues  as  of 
May 2006. The number of listed issues has grown by more than 200% since 2002. This growth 
reflects  the  increasing  role  of  the  bond  market  as  an  alternative  means  of  financing  for 
corporations.  Total  market  cap  of  corporate  bonds  is  about  $6.5  billion,  most  of  which  are 
concentrated in the banking and financial sector. 13  
 
24. 
The Government is the  principal issuer in the bond market. Other issuers include local 
banks,  mining,  oil  and  gas  firms,  and  state-owned  and  private  corporations.  Most  bond 
purchasers are long-term investors with no intention of reselling their bonds on the secondary 
market.  Around  80%  are  domestic  financial  institutions.  The  rest  are  mutual  funds,  pension 
funds,  foreign  financial  institutions,  insurance  companies,  and  individuals.  The  secondary 
market is thin, with no efficient mechanism for obtaining bid–ask prices.  
 

3. 

Main  Development  Challenges  Calling  for  the  Development  of  Domestic 
Bond Markets and Securitization 

25. 
A vibrant capital market is crucial for economic development. The Asian financial crisis 
has confirmed the need to develop the long-term domestic bond markets in the region. Despite 
generally  high  rates  of  savings,  long-term  savings  have  not  been  efficiently  mobilized.  Private 
sector investments in rapidly growing emerging economies have had to be financed with short-
term  foreign  borrowing.  To  avoid  the  risk  of  such  mismatches,  governments  in  ADB’s 
developing member countries (DMCs) have been looking for ways to address this issue. 
 
Underdeveloped bond markets narrow a country’s choice in raising capital, leading them 
26. 
to  rely  heavily  on  the  banking  system.  Banks,  on  the  other  hand,  risk  mismatches  in  their 
maturity structures if they continue to provide long-term capital given their short-term liabilities. 
For  lack  of  alternative  sources  of  domestic  long-term  capital,  firms  have  often  turned  to 
international wholesale credit markets, and have exposed themselves to exchange rate risks in 
the  payment  of  debt.  The  Asian  financial  crisis,  however,  has  worsened  those  risks,  and  has 
reduced  the  flow  of  portfolio  lending  to  Asian  countries.  Little  long-term  capital  is  being 
mobilized in the region. Clearly, domestic bond markets have a crucial role to play, along with 
domestic  equity  markets,  in  financing  investments  in  areas  critical  to  sustained  economic 
growth.  Reforms  in  these  markets  are  thus  a  key  part  of  financial  market  reform  in  Asia  in 
general.  

27. 
In  line  with  this  rationale,  and  in  order  to  develop  an  active  and  liquid  debt  market  for 
government  and  corporate  bonds,  the  Government  is  applying  strategic  measures  to  improve 
the  regulatory  framework,  corporate  governance,  trading  and  clearing  systems,  and  other 
necessary market infrastructure, as it positions the public debt market to become a significant 
financing tool for domestic corporations, SMEs, and local governments.  
 
28. 
The  creation  of  fixed-income  bonds,  from  a  pool  of  otherwise  illiquid  loans  through  a 
securitization  process,  will  help  spur  the  development  of  the  domestic  capital  market  in 
investment 
Indonesia.  At  present, 

for  securitization  encourages 

framework 

legal 

the 

                                                 
12 Bapepam. 2005. Indonesian Capital Market Master Plan 2005-2009. Jakarta. 
13  Surabaya Stock Exchange website, http://www.bes.co.id/market/stBond.asp. 

 

  6 

the 

lending;  (ii)  given 

opportunities  and  cross-border  transactions.  However,  the  process  is  very  cumbersome  and 
difficult. Transactions are therefore usually structured outside the existing regulatory framework.  
 
29. 
Several factors call for the development of the securitization market: (i) the development 
of  the  bond  and  securitization  market,  in  particular,  would  reduce  the  problem  of  credit 
tightening  as  it  would  release  scarce  capital  of  the  Indonesian  banks  and  other  financial 
institutions  (FIs)  enabling  new 
increased  competitiveness  and 
consolidation  process  in  the  financial  and  corporate  sectors,  securitization  would  allow  banks 
and  finance  companies  to  increase  their  returns  by  redeploying  the  same  equity.  A  financial 
institution can extend loans at market rates, and then securitize a pool at a lower rate because 
of diversification and the efficiencies inherent in tranching cash flows. With FIs becoming more 
conscious of the cost of capital and more aware of the need to diversify their sources of funding, 
securitization  of  loan  portfolios  would  become  a  core  tool  of  balance-sheet  management;  (iii) 
securitization would offer the FIs a new kind of intermediary role by redistributing credit risk in 
the same way that an insurance provider pools individuals’ exposures to loss or accident. Under 
the  traditional  model,  banks  performed  this  by  matching  pools  of  borrowing  with  pools  of 
deposits.  In  securitization,  they  package  credit  for  capital  markets  investors  rather  than 
depositors.  
 
30. 
Securitization  offers  effective  means  of  improving  the  capital  adequacy  of  the  banking 
and financial sectors, both of which are critical elements in improving the overall performance of 
the  Indonesian  financial  sector.  The  development  of  the  securitization  market  will  aid  in  the 
growth and development of the corporate bond market, in particular:  
 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

Credit  rating  culture.  Based  on  international  past  precedents,  an  independent 
credit  rating  system  represents  a  key  component  to  the  development  of  a  well-
functioning  corporate  bond  market.  Only  when  investors  have  comfort  in  an 
independent rating system will they be able to properly assess the true credit risk 
in corporate and other bonds.  

Credit  pricing  process.  Securitization  issuance  will  also  develop  the  credit 
pricing curve. Securitization results directly in the sophistication, consistency, and 
transparency of the credit pricing process.  

Increasing  number  of 
investors.  With  the  growth  of  the 
securitization market, more institutional investors will come to Indonesia, serving 
to enhance competition and increase liquidity for the market as a whole. 

institutional 

Diversification  for  investors. Securitization issuance and the supply of a wide 
range of new financial assets will enable institutional investors to better achieve 
their goals of creating stable, diversified asset portfolios that offer them a better 
chance of achieving their return and risk management objectives. 

Project  Selection  and  Strategic  Approach  of  the  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department 

 
E. 

In  line  with  the  revised  medium-term  strategy  (MTS  II),  ADB  aims  to  expand  its 
31. 
cofinancing  operations,  especially  guarantee  operations.  One  focus  on  such  expansion  is  to 
provide credit guarantees in support of capital markets, i.e., to guarantee the issue of securities, 
including corporate issues or asset-backed securities.  
 
 
 

 

  

 

 

7

F. 

Country and Sector Strategy 

The  country  strategy  and  program  (CSP)  for  Indonesia  2003–2005 14  calls  special 
32. 
attention  to  the  need  to  foster  a  vibrant  and  competitive  private  sector  and  foresees  not  only 
public sector operations but especially direct investments by PSOD to achieve this goal. One of 
the  main  strategic  target  areas is  “to  support the  reform  and  development  of  a  diversified and 
sound  financial  sector  that  can  provide  effective  intermediation  of  savings  through  improved 
financial institutions and markets, including banks” but also through the capital markets.  
 
33. 
The CSP is being updated. The initiating draft focuses on reviving the private sector in 
Indonesia  as  a  key  success  factor  for  Indonesia’s  future  to  stimulate  domestic  and  foreign 
investments.  In  particular,  the  much  needed  deepening  of  the  financial  sector  is  seen  as  a 
prerequisite for long-term development and is therefore one of the main strategic focus areas of 
the  new  CSP.  The  banking  sector  plays  a  dominant  role,  accounting  for  over  82%  of  overall 
assets. Capital markets have grown in importance in recent years, but long-term debt issuance 
has  until  recently  been  limited  to  government  bonds.  All  in  all,  the  capital  markets  play  only  a 
limited role. This is why the CSP calls for an improvement of this situation. 
 
34. 
It  has  been  agreed  that  special  attention  will  be  paid  to  private  sector  operations,  and 
that ADB will strengthen its focus on Indonesia as a priority destination for direct investments in 
the  private  sector.  ADB  will  explore  various  opportunities  in  the  financial  sector  with  a  special 
focus  on  domestic  capital  market  development  and  the  development  of  a  cross-border  and 
domestic securitizations market. As such, the proposed transaction is in line with the existing as 
well as the anticipated new strategy for Indonesia. 
 
ADB has been active in promoting the Asian Bond Market Initiative (ABMI),15 which was 
35. 
proposed  by  the  Government  of  Japan  in  December  2002  and  under  which  various  efforts  to 
develop  bond  markets  have  been  underway  within  the  framework  of  ASEAN+3  (Japan,  the 
PRC,  and  Republic  of  Korea).  ADB  promotes  the  ABMI  inter  alia  through  the  use  of  its 
guarantee products. 
 

III. 

THE PROJECT SPONSOR AND MARKET BACKGROUND 

A. 

Deutsche Bank AG 

36. 
Deutsche Bank AG is the largest bank in Germany in terms of total assets, and one of 
the most diversified financial institutions on a global level.16 As of 31 December 2004, the group 
provided  services  to  56,434  corporate  and  investment  bank  clients,  3,722  institutional  asset-
management clients, 13.3 million personal customers, 111,000 private banking clients, and 7.7 

                                                 
14 ADB. 2002. Country Strategy and Program (2003-2005): Indonesia. Manila. 
15  The ABMI was launched as a measure to prevent the recurrence of the Asian currency crisis by channeling funds 
in  the  Asian  region,  which  is  characterized  by  a  high  savings  rate,  to  investments  within  the  region.  Currently, 
discussions are underway among the governments of ASEAN+3 countries on ways to develop and invigorate bond 
markets in Asian countries. 

16 Business  activities  are  categorized  along  three  group  divisions:  (i)  Corporate  and  Investment  Bank  (CIB):  this 
division  is  focused  on  private  and  public  sector  clients,  SMEs,  in  addition  to  global  corporates.  Activities 
encompass capital markets, advisory, and lending; (ii) Private Clients and Asset Management (PCAM): the focus of 
this division is on small businesses and private clients in Germany, Italy, Spain, Belgium, and Poland, in addition to 
globally bound asset management activities conducted via  its retail franchises in Europe (DWS Investments) and 
the US (Scudder Investments). Tailored financing solutions are offered to high net worth clients of Deutsche Bank; 
(iii) Corporate Investments (CI): this division covers industrial shareholdings, other holdings and bank-occupied real 
estate assets, private equity, and venture capital activities.  

 

 

  8 

million retail asset-management customers. The group is actively present in 74 countries via a 
network  of  1,559  branches,  respective  offices  and  subsidiaries.  Additional  distribution  is 
achieved via mobile advisors, Internet, telephone banking and third party distribution initiatives. 
As at 31 March 2005, the bank employed 64,527 full-time staff. 
 
37. 
Deutsche  Bank  AG’s  operations  are  supported  by  a  reassuring  level  of  economic 
capitalization  and  are  steered  by  sophisticated  and  efficient  risk  management.  The  bank  is 
expected to continue to generate excess economic capital from recurring earnings. The current 
phase  of  Deutsche  Bank  AG’s  restructuring  program  is  focused  on  ongoing  cost  control,  risk 
management,  and  enhanced  revenue  generation  (through  greater  leveraging  of its  franchises) 
and should help to improve the bank’s risk-return profile in domestic and global markets.  
 
Deutsche Bank AG reported an operating profit of €6.1 billion and a net income of €3.5 
38. 
billion  for  2005,  up  by  52%  and  47%,  respectively,  year-on-year  and  primarily  reflecting  good 
revenue  growth  and  moderate  cost  increases.  Total  assets  stood  at  €992  billion,  backed  by 
equity  of  €29.9  billion  and  a  solid  tier-1  ratio  of  8.7%.  Deutsche  Bank  AG  is  rated  Aa3  by 
Moody’s and AA- by S&P and Fitch. 
 
B. 

The Indonesian Motorcycle Industry 

In  Indonesia,  motorcycles  are  a  major  alternative  mode  of  transportation  for  the 
39. 
populace  as  it  is  often  more  efficient  and  economical  than  existing  public  transportation. 
However, Indonesia has a low motorcycle user ratio. Notably, there is only one motorcycle per 
eight  to  nine  Indonesians,  compared  to  one  in  every  three  to  four  Thais  and  one  to  two 
Taiwanese.  
 
40. 
As  proven  by  industrialized  countries  such  as  the  Republic  of  Korea,  Malaysia,  and 
various countries in Latin America (the development paths of which in turn follow that of Europe 
and  even  the  US),  the  growth  in  the  automobile  population  is  strongly  related  to  the  country’s 
per capita income. In the case of Indonesia, the Asian economic crisis resulted in a sharp drop 
in  the  country’s  purchasing  power,  with  GDP  per  head  falling  59%  to  $469  in  1998,  which,  in 
turn, led to a sharp decline in total motor sales. Motorcycle sales rebounded from 1998 to 2000 
as  the  economy  stabilized  but  remained  flat  in  2001.  2003  continued  to  see  sales  growth 
despite  the  Iraq  war,  the  SARS  outbreak,  and  the  military  assault  on  the  northern  province  of 
Aceh. For perspective, from 2000 to 2004, the compounded annual growth rate totaled 13% for 
automobiles  and  45%  for  motorcycles,  but  in  2004  (because  of  easier  credit  access),  the 
automobile and motorcycle market showed an averaged growth of 37%, which was higher than 
that of Malaysia and Thailand.  
 
41. 
There is considerable scope for further growth in the motorcycle industry because of the 
large  population  (in  excess  of  210  million),  low  levels  of  motorcycle  ownership,  increasing 
affluence, and rising credit availability. The above describe revived growth of motorcycle sales 
in the last two years is expected to continue, which should lead to a recovery to pre-crisis sales 
levels  in  2006.  Please  refer  to  figure  Appendix  3  for  a  graphic  illustration  of  the  historic 
motorcycle  sales  development  from  1995  to  2006.  Three  key  Japanese  brands  (Honda, 
Yamaha, Suzuki) dominate the market with approximately 96% total market share.  
 
 
 
 
 
 

  

 

A. 

Project Overview, Outcome and Objectives 

IV. 

THE PROJECT 

 

 

9

42. 
ADB will finance the acquisition by DB of two portfolios of motorcycle loans (Portfolio 1 
and  Portfolio  2,  together  the  Portfolios)  from  the  Company,  based  on  predetermined  Eligibility 
Criteria. The Portfolios were originated by the Company.  It is envisaged that ADB will (i) provide 
a  credit  guarantee  to  DB  with  respect  to  principal  and  potentially  interest  to  a  second  loss 
portion of the Portfolios (Guaranteed Portion) by way of a (partial) credit guarantee (Guarantee) 
or  PCG;  and  (ii)  finance  by  way  of  a  funded  participation  (or  other  similar  instrument)  in  an 
amount of up to $200,000 (or its rupiah equivalent), the senior tranche (Senior Tranche) of the 
Portfolios  acquired  by  DB.  It  is  anticipated  that  (i)  DB  and  the  Company  will  retain  a  first  loss 
amount  with  respect  to  principal  repayments  of  up  to  a  certain  percentage  of  the  Portfolio;  (ii) 
ADB will guarantee amounts over the first loss amount up to a certain percentage, representing 
the second loss amount on the Portfolios; and (iii) ADB will guarantee principal and potentially 
also  the  interest  portion  of  the  Guaranteed  Portion.  The  Company  will  act  as  servicer  with 
respect to the Portfolios.  
 
43. 
issuance of reference note to a group of investors.  
 
B. 

After  an  initial  warehousing  period,  DB  will  securitize  part  of  the  Portfolios  through  the 

Portfolio Selection  

 

DB has selected and purchased from the Company Portfolio 1 in February 2006 and will 
44. 
select  and  purchase  a  Portfolio  2  (together  the  Portfolios)  from  the  Company  once  ADB  has 
received all necessary approvals.  
 
 

 

V. 

THE PROPOSED ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK FINANCING 

A. 

Asian Development Bank Partial Credit Guarantee  

45. 
The ADB Guarantee will be a guarantee on the second loss portion of the Portfolios.  It 
is  envisaged  that  losses  will  be  calculated  at  the  end  of  the  maturity  of  the  Guarantee,  which 
coincides  with  the  maturity  of  the  Portfolios.  ADB  will  guarantee  the  principal,  and  may  also 
partially cover interest. 
 
B. 

Participation Agreement 

46. 
ADB will make an anchor  investment of up to $100,000 (or its rupiah equivalent) in each 
of the Portfolios by way of a limited recourse funded Participation Agreement with DB, pursuant 
to  which  ADB  will  receive  a  pro  rata  interest  in  collections  of  the  Senior  Tranche  of  the 
Portfolios. 
 
C. 

Main Terms and Conditions 

The proposed ADB guarantee and limited recourse participation agreement will contain 

47. 
terms and conditions applicable to a transaction of this nature.  
 
48. 
fees involved in accordance with market rates and spreads available in the Project. 
 

The  Guarantee  Committee  will  determine  the  guarantee  fee  under  the  PCG  and  other

VI. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Justification of the Proposed ADB Assistance 

1. 

Development Impact and Effectiveness 

The proposed ADB funding will promote development at the following key levels: 

 
49. 
 
50. 
Develop  the  Capital  Market.  The  to-be-issued  reference  notes  will  be  sold  in  the 
Indonesian  domestic  bond  market.  This  will  (i)  have  a  demonstration  effect  with  respect  to 
modern  capital  market  technology;  (ii)  increase  liquidity  in  the  domestic  market,  including 
attraction of foreign capital investment and creation of a secondary market for Indonesian loan 
assets;  (iii)  promote  price  discovery  for  this  nascent  and  complex  class  of  assets;  and  (iv) 
establish  pricing  benchmarks  for  similar  assets  as  well  as  term  structures  for  other  types  of 
assets. The growth of the domestic bond markets will provide the much needed counterweight 
to the dominant banking market. 
 
51. 
Fostering the Retail Lending Market in Indonesia. The sale of the Portfolios frees up 
capital  of  the  Company  and  balances  its  debt-to-equity  ratio,  enabling  further  lending  and 
growth. ADB’s due diligence process and the design of the Eligibility Criteria provides know-how 
transfer in terms of pool analysis and loan underwriting. 
 
52.

support  to  the  Indonesian  Government  in  its  efforts  to  create  a  deeper  and  more  developed 
capital markets.

ASSURANCE 

59. 
A framework agreement relating to ADB’s status, privileges, and immunities with respect 
to ADB’s lending, guarantee, and equity operations in the private sector is in effect between the 
Indonesian  Government  and  ADB.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian 
Development  Bank,  the  Indonesian  Government  will  be  requested  to  confirm  that  it  has  no 
objection to the proposed ADB financial assistance to DB. No funding will be disbursed until the 
no-objection letter is obtained. 
 
ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  guarantee  agreements,  and  other  legally  required 
60. 
documents,  following  approval  of  the  proposed  financing  by  ADB’s  Board  of  Directors.  These 
agreements will be on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB. In addition, ADB will need to be 
satisfied  with  all  terms  and  conditions  of  the  other  principal  documents  associated  with  the 
proposed financial assistance.

Appendix 1 

13

 

INDONESIAN BANKING SECTOR—MAIN ISSUES 

 
1. 
The less certain operating climate in the second half 2005, with higher oil prices, inflation 
and  sharply  higher  interest  rates  (up  500bp),  caused  profitability  to  ease  and  loan  quality  to 
weaken among the Indonesian banks. This was greatly compounded by “technical downgrades” 
arising from stricter nonperforming loan (NPL) classification requirements.  
 
2. 
The broader public sector risks posed by the tougher operating environment and rising 
interest  rate  environment  for  banks  should  be  limited  by  the  introduction  of  stricter  NPL 
classification  requirements  by  Bank  Indonesia  (BI),  as  well  as  improvements  in  state  bank 
governance and increased foreign ownership of banking system assets. 
 
It is estimated that the sector’s return on assets fell to 1.8% in the first 9 months of 2005 
3. 
versus 2.6% in full-year 2004, although this was still a reasonably strong performance, even by 
regional standards. The gross NPL ratio doubled to 10% versus 2.6% in full-year 2004 – mainly 
owing  to  the  technical  downgrades,  as  mentioned  above,  although  there  was  also  some 
deterioration  in  underlying  loan  quality,  as  reflected  by  the  increase  in  special  mention  loans 
posted by a few banks.  
 
4. 
Although NPLs need to be closely monitored, given the higher interest rate environment, 
mitigating factors still exist in the form of low system leverage, diversified loan books, good core 
profitability and the banks’ generally quite strong capital positions.  
 
5. 
CAR: 15%, Total CAR: 20.  
 
6. 
Indonesian  banks  continued  to  rebuild  their  loan  books  over  2005,  albeit  from  a  small 
base (after huge, Asian-crisis-induced write-offs) with an emphasis on small-and medium sized 
enterprises  (SME)  and  consumer  lending.  These  now  account  for  roughly  40%  and  30%  of 
loans,  respectively,  while  corporate  loans  have  fallen  to  some  30%  from  a  pre-crisis  share  of 
60%-70%. 
 
 

The sector’s equity to assets ratio held steady at 10% as of end-September 2005 (Tier 1 

 

 14 

Appendix 2 

 
A. 

Overview1 

INDONESIAN RETAIL BANKING MARKET 

Indonesia’s  retail  banking  market  has  expanded  rapidly  since  the  1997-1998  Asian 
1. 
financial crisis, fed by stronger economic growth and lower interest rates, increased confidence 
with the improved political situation in the country, and the Indonesian banks’ desire to rebuild 
and diversify their loan books following the massive corporate loan write-offs arising out of the 
crisis.  Between  end-1999  and  end-September  2005  commercial  banks’  total  lending  to 
individuals grew by a compounded average growth rate (CAGR) of 44% and outpaced the 21% 
increase in overall banking system loans. 
 
However,  growth  emanated  from  a  very  small  base,  with  central  bank  data  suggesting 
2. 
lending to individuals stood at just 7%-8% of GDP share, reflecting the banks’ historical lack of 
focus  on  consumer  loans  and  the  quite  small  size  of  the  Indonesian  consumer  market.  Other 
influencing  factors  are  the  geographical  diversity  of  the  country  and  the  prevalence  of  a  large 
rural  population  base  and  the  general  inaccessibility  of  basic  banking  services  for  a  sizeable 
portion  of  the  population.  It  also  reflects  low  income  levels  and  limited  borrowing  ability: 
mortgage  loans  account  for  only  20%  of  consumer  lending;  almost  half  is  for  purchase  of 
motorbikes. This is clearly not low-risk lending but the risk-return profile appears reasonable in 
the context of delinquency ratios of 2%-3% (3Q 2005) and average interest margins of close to 
5%. 
 
3. 
Nevertheless,  individual  lending  has  grown  to  about  30%  of  banking  system  loans  at 
end-September  2005  from  just  10%  in  1997;  SME-commercial  loans  are  estimated  at 
Approximately  40%  and  corporate  loans  at  approximately  30%  (a  sharp  reduction  from  60%-
70%  pre-crisis).  However,  the  overall  share  of retail  loans to  total loans  is,  according  to  Fitch, 
likely to be slightly higher, possibly closer to 35%. 
 
4. 
With  lending  to  individuals,  the  segmental  breakdown  is  estimated  as  follows:  45% 
automotive  (including  motorcycles),  20%  residential  mortgages,  10%  credit  cards,  and  25% 
micro-credits  and  other  personal  loans.  Growth  has  been  led  by  the  financing  of  motorcycles 
(where  sales  have  increased  by  30%-40%  over  2004-2005),  residential  properties,  cars  and 
other micro-credits. 
 
5. 
framework was established in early 2005 for a more comprehensive platform to be developed. 
 
B. 
 
The 12 larger Indonesian banks show gross consumer NPL rates of no more than 2%-
6. 
3%  of  their  consumer  loan  portfolio  as  at  September  2005  compared  with  an  overall  banking 
system gross NPL ratio of 9%-10%. The high overall NPL rate reflects an overhang of corporate 
and  commercial  NPLs  emanating  from  the  Asian  financial  crisis  while  the  low  consumer  NPL 
figure has been partly diluted by the banks’ strong expansion.  
 
7. 
Credit  assessment  and  risk  management  processes  in  this  area  are  still  evolving. 
Hence, the recent sharp spike in domestic interest rates, with the 1-month SBI upped by 550bp 
over  2005,  may  cause  some  deterioration  in  consumer  loan  quality  and  ease  the  pace  of 
lending in 2006. The system-wide impact, however, should be mitigated by the still low level of 
                                                 
1 This section is based on Fitch. Indonesian Retail Lending Market, 2006. 

There  is  currently  no  nationwide  credit  bureau  in  Indonesia,  although  a  regulatory 

Nonperforming Loans 

 Appendix 2 

15 

consumer  leverage,  the  stronger  financial  shape  of  the  larger  banks  and  the  support  that  is 
likely  to  be  forthcoming  for  several  of  the  now  foreign-owned  private  national  banks.  Rising 
affluence  and  a  growing  middle  class  in  Indonesia  are  also  other  factors  that  should  help 
underpin  the  long-term  growth  prospects  for  the  retail  loan  market  in  Indonesia.  The  key 
uncertainty  in  2006  is  how  much  negative  impact  higher  interest  rates  will  have  on  consumer 
credit quality. 
 
C. 

Outlook for Consumer Lending in Indonesia  

8. 
The underdeveloped consumer lending market of Indonesia has room to grow for many 
years but the lesson to draw from the recent experience of Republic of Korea is that effective 
risk  management  tools  are  essential.  However,  access  to  good  information  combined  with 
reasonably  sophisticated  risk  management  systems  will  not  prevent  bad  debt  problems  if 
lenders  are  too  aggressive  in  extending  credit  to  new  borrowers,  who  are  inevitably 
inexperienced  in  managing  personal  borrowing,  making  it  too  easy  for  them  to  take  on 
excessive debts. 
 
9. 
In this respect, finance companies have several advantages over banks in the marketing 
and  collection  of  such  loans  through  their  grassroots-based  staff  and  offices.  Recently,  the 
industry  consolidated  the  four  larger  finance  companies  in  Indonesia  that  are  either  majority 
owned by banks (Adira Finance and WOM are now owned by Danamon and BII respectively) or 
affiliated to a bank (via Astra which holds a stake in Bank Permata).

• Decrease in interest rates on consumer lending 
 
 
• Contribution to financial strength of sector (e.g., 
better match of assets to liabilities, improved capital 
adequacy and lending limit requirements, risk transfer 
through securitization process) 
• Share in total financial sector assets of private sector 
nonbank financial institutions growing to comparable 
levels in more developed Asian countries (Taiwan, 
Malaysia) or developed countries (Western Europe, 
US) 
 
 

 • Deepening and development of 
the capital markets (creation of an 
active securitization and domestic 
bond market) 
 
 

 

 

Appendix 4 

19

• Eventual issuance of fixed-income notes and/or 
bonds from the acquired loan portfolio through a 
securitization process 
• Evidence of spill over effects, e.g., other financial 
institutions begin the process of securitization of their 
respective assets (two over the next two years) 
• Other financial institutions replicating the developed 
structure (two over the next two years) 
• Changes in the existing legislation in the next five 
years enabling a full scale securitization market in 
Indonesia 
• Overall development of the bond market in Indonesia 
in the next five years into a more diversified corporate 
bond market
